results.title: Ratopolis
results.creator_credit: Gilles Therien, Francois Seguillon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A study of the wily brown rat, humankind’s unwanted companion throughout the world, whose bite on the world’s food resources adds to the growing threat of shortage. In a normal, free-ranging environment, the rat is more than a match for its hosts and colonies flourish. Under abnormal conditions of restricted space and limited food, a rat colony loses all “social” constraints on behavior. The film has implicit analogies for all animal behavior, including humanity’s. Plagues, predators and extermination attempts are among the topics discussed.

results.title: Ratatouille
results.creator_credit: Jan Pinkava, Brad Bird, Brad Lewis, Pixar Animation Studios and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: Writer/director Brad Bird (“The Incredibles”) brings us this hilariously inventive tale of Remy, a rat with poetry in his soul and magic in his cooking. Accidentally separated from his family, Remy coincidentally arrives at the former restaurant of his chef hero, Gusteau, and seizes an opportunity to secretly create a soup that is a menu hit. Discovered and threatened with destruction, Remy teams up with the hapless garbage-boy, Linguini, to create the best food in Paris (and therefore, of course, the best food in the world!). While Linguini takes credit for the culinary art they produce, it is actually Remy exercising creative control (sitting under Linguini’s chef’s hat and steering his actions by pulling on his hair). The restaurant’s resulting wild success attracts the interest of the feared food critic, Anton Ego (voiced by Peter O’Toole), but a mass walkout of kitchen staff on the night Ego visits threatens disaster. It’s rats to the rescue as Remy’s family and clan take over the running of the kitchen while Remy creates his masterpiece - ratatouille - for Ego, warming the critic’s icy heart, and winning a good review for Gusteau’s in the process. Beautifully drawn animation complements the quality of the witty script, with its highly developed characterisations and thoughtful reflections on cross-cultural prejudice, the role and power of the critic, the commodification of art, and the weight of conflicting loyalties to family and one’s own dreams. With appeal for both adults and children, and food lovers of all ages, “Ratatouille” may be a genuine example of that rarity, a true “family picture.” Cast also includes the voices of: Patton Oswalt (as Remy), Ian Holm (as the villainous chef Skinner), Janeane Garofalo (as the tough female chef Colette), and Lou Romano (as Linguini). (Awards: Winner of 2007 Academy Award for Best Animated Picture.)

results.title: Rambo: first blood. Part II
results.creator_credit: George Pan Cosmatos, Buzz Feitshans and Tri-Star Pictures
results.brief_description: Rambo is sent on a secret mission to help the U.S. Government find remaining Prisoners of War in Vietnam. However, although the mission is designed to fail, the bureaucrats did not take into account Rambo’s fierce determination, courage and skill to bring them back - alone if necessary. Rambo is launched into the jungle and the film explodes into one fireball action sequence after another.

results.title: Rambo III
results.creator_credit: Peter MacDonald, Buzz Feitshans and Carolco Pictures
results.brief_description: Considered by many critics to be the best of the three films in the Rambo: ‘First Blood trilogy.’ The film’s plot takes on a righteous turn as the “universal soldier” Rambo seeks to liberate a group of Afghans from under the regime of a brutal Russian General. The action sequences in this film are both spectacular and terrifying, and the enigmatic, not altogether two dimensional character of Rambo rises above the conflagration with more style than in the previous films.

results.title: Raku: the ancient art of Japanese ceramics
results.creator_credit: G Roy Levin and Charles Cahill
results.brief_description: The raku process began in the 12th century in Japan growing out of a Zen Buddhist religious ceremony. Raku firing offers the potter many advantages over other techniques, and provides an intimacy and immediacy more deeply felt than any other ceramic process. Narrated by Ann Dumaresq.

results.title: Rajneesh: Spiritual Terrorist
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Connop and Vision Quest Films
results.brief_description: From all over the world thousands of affluent and educated seekers flock to the Rajneesh’s ashram in Poona, India. We gain access to the Rajneesh and to the exotic private and public lifestyles that have earned him headlines around the world. The documentary also provides intimate portraits of some of the disciples around Rajneesh, including a young American actor, a former CIA agent, a German princess, a young Australian and Rajneesh’s personal dentist.

results.title: Raising Victor Vargas
results.creator_credit: Peter Sollett, Scott Macaulay, Robin O'hara, Alain de la Mata and Studio Canal
results.brief_description: Victor (Victor Rasuk) a New York City teenager gets caught trying to sleep with ‘Fat Donna’ when his younger sister Vicki (Krystal Rodriguez) realises what he’s up to and spreads the word in the neighbourhood. Victor, thinking his reputation has suffered a blow, quells the summer heat with a visit to the local public pool with his best friend Harold. Here he meets ‘Juicy Judy’ (Judy Marte) and he decides to pursue her. Living in a small apartment with his strict Grandmother, sister and piano-playing younger brother Nino (Rasuk’s real-life brother Silvestre), Victor finds life as a teenager challenging when he gets the blame for having a bad influence on his siblings. Coming-of-age is tough (and sometimes comical) for Victor as he finds real love, gets a glimpse of what manhood is about and asserts his place within the family. Based on the short film “Five Feet High and Rising” by its writer/director Peter Sollett. Cast also includes Kevin Rivera, Altagracia Guzman, Melonie Diaz.

results.title: Raising the standard
results.creator_credit: John Spencer, James Carr, British Productivity Council and World Wide
results.brief_description: Discusses the British standard of living and relates it to productivity and ways in which both may be improved. Reorganising of work is essential, and problems involved are shown. The most important of these is the attitude and, not infrequently, the opposition of workers. There is a greater need for tactful handling of problems on the part of management. Labor must realise that more work, which leads to increased productivity, means higher standard of living and not simply higher profits and dividends. The film concludes with a discussion on these points.
